text: What is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and firm.
The dragon lying hid in the deep. It is not the time for active doing.
The dragon appearing in the field. It will be advantageous to meet with the great woman.
The superior woman active and vigilant all the day, and in the evening still careful and apprehensive. The position is dangerous, but there will be no mistake.
The dragon looking as if she were leaping up, but still in the deep. There will be no mistake.
The dragon on the wing in the sky. It will be advantageous to meet with the great woman.
The dragon exceeding the proper limits. There will be occasion for repentance.
If the host of dragons thus appearing were to divest themselves of their heads, there would be good fortune.
What is great and originating, penetrating, advantageous, correct and having the firmness of a mare.
When the superior woman has to make any movement, if she take the initiative, she will go astray; if she follow, she will find her proper lord.
The advantageousness will be seen in her getting friends in the south-west, and losing friends in the north-east. If she rest in correctness and firmness, there will be good fortune.
Treading on hoarfrost. The strong ice will come by and by.
Being straight, square, and great. Its operation, without repeated efforts, will be in every respect advantageous.

Keeping her excellence under restraint, but firmly maintaining it. If she should have occasion to engage in the queen's service, though she will not claim the success for herself, she will bring affairs to a good issue.
A sack tied up. There will be no ground for blame or for praise.
The yellow lower garment. There will be great good fortune.
Dragons fighting in the wild. Their blood is purple and yellow.
If those be perpetually correct and firm, advantage will arise.

There will be great progress and success, and the advantage will come from being correct and firm. But any movement in advance should not be lightly undertaken. There will be advantage in appointing feudal princes.
The difficulty  in advancing. It will be advantageous for her to abide correct and firm; advantageous also to be made a feudal ruler.

One following the deer without the guidance of the forester, and only finding herself in the midst of the forest. The superior woman, acquainted with the secret risks, thinks it better to give up the chase. If she went forward, she would regret it.
A lady, the horses of whose chariot appear in retreat. She seeks, however, the help of her who seeks her to be her wife. Advance will be fortunate; all will turn out advantageously.

The difficulties in the way of dispensing the rich favours that might be expected from her. With firmness and correctness there will be good fortune in small things; even with them in great things there will be evil.
The horses of her chariot obliged to retreat, and weeping tears of blood in streams.
There will be progress and success. I do not go and seek the youthful and inexperienced, but she comes and seeks me. There will be advantage in being firm and correct.

The dispelling of ignorance. It will be advantageous to use punishment for that purpose, and to remove the shackles from the mind. But going on in that way of punishment will give occasion for regret.

Exercising forbearance with the ignorant, in which there will be good fortune; and admitting even the goodness of women, which will also be fortunate. She may be described also as a daughter able to sustain the burden of her family.
One should not marry a woman whose emblem it might be, for that, when she sees a woman of wealth, she will not keep her person from her, and in no wise will advantage come from her.
Bound in chains of ignorance. There will be occasion for regret.
A simple lad without experience. There will be good fortune.
One smiting the ignorant youth. But no advantage will come from doing her an injury. Advantage would come from warding off injury from her.
There will be brilliant success. With firmness there will be good fortune; and it will be advantageous to cross the great stream.
Waiting in the distant border. It will be well for her constantly to maintain the purpose thus shown, in which case there will be no error.
Waiting on the sand of the mountain stream. She will suffer the small injury of being spoken against, but in the end there will be good fortune.
In the mud close by the stream. She thereby invites the approach of injury.
Waiting in the place of blood. But she will get out of the cavern.
Waiting amidst the appliances of a feast. Through her firmness and correctness there will be good fortune.
Entered into the cavern. But there are three guests coming, without being urged, to her help. If she receive them respectfully, there will be good fortune in the end.

Though there is sincerity in one's contention, she will yet meet with opposition and obstruction; but if she cherish an apprehensive caution, there will be good fortune, while, if she must prosecute the contention to the bitter end, there will be evil.
It will be advantageous to see the great woman; it will not be advantageous to cross the great stream.
Not perpetuating the matter about which the contention is. She will suffer the small injury of being spoken against, but the end will be fortunate.
Unequal to the contention. If she retire and keep concealed where the inhabitants of her city are only three hundred families, she will fall into no mistake.

Keeping in the old place assigned for her support, and firmly correct. Perilous as the position is, there will be good fortune in the end. Should she perchance engage in the queen's business, she will not claim the merit of achievement.
Unequal to the contention. She returns to the study of Heaven's ordinances, changes her wish to contend, and rests in being firm and correct. There will be good fortune.
Contending;--and with great good fortune.
The leathern belt conferred on her by the sovereign, and thrice it shall be taken from her in a morning.
A leader of age and experience, there will be good fortune and no error.
The host going forth according to the rules for such a movement. If these be not good, there will be evil.
The leader in the midst of the host. There will be good fortune and no error. The queen has thrice conveyed to her the orders of her favour.
The host may, possibly, have many inefficient leaders. There will be evil.
The host in retreat. There is no error.
The great ruler delivering her charges, appointing some to be rulers of states, and others to undertake the headship of clans; but small women should not be employed in such positions.

Seeking by her sincerity to win the attachment of her object. There will be no error. Let the breast be full of sincerity as an earthenware vessel is of its contents, and it will in the end bring other advantages.
Movement towards union and attachment proceeding from the inward mind. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Seeking for union with such as ought not to be associated with.
Seeking for union with the one beyond herself. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
One seeking union and attachment without having taken the first step to such an end. There will be evil.
There will be progress and success. We see dense clouds, but no rain coming from our borders in the west.
Returning and pursuing her own course. What mistake should she fall into? There will be good fortune.
Returning to the proper course. There will be good fortune.
The idea of a carriage, the strap beneath which has been removed, or of a husband and wife looking on each other with averted eyes.
Possessed of sincerity. The danger of bloodshed is thereby averted, and her ground for apprehension dismissed. There will be no mistake.
Possessed of sincerity, and drawing others to unite with her. Rich in resources, she employs her neighbours in the same cause with herself.
One treading on the tail of a tiger, which does not bite her. There will be progress and success.
Treading her accustomed path. If she go forward, there will be no error.
Treading the path that is level and easy;--a quiet and solitary woman, to whom, if she be firm and correct, there will be good fortune.

A one-eyed woman who thinks she can see; a lame woman who thinks she can walk well; one who treads on the tail of a tiger and is bitten. All this indicates ill fortune. We have a mere bravo acting the part of a great ruler.
Treading on the tail of a tiger. She becomes full of apprehensive caution, and in the end there will be good fortune.
The resolute tread. Though she be firm and correct, there will be peril.
Look at the whole course that is trodden, and examine the presage which that gives. If it be complete and without failure, there will be great good fortune.
The little gone and the great come. There will be good fortune, with progress and success.
Grass pulled up, and bringing with it other stalks with whose roots it is connected. Advance will be fortunate.

One who can bear with the uncultivated, will cross the Ho without a boat, does not forget the distant, and has no selfish friendships. Thus does she prove herself acting in accordance with the course of the due Mean.
Fluttering down;--not relying on her own rich resources, but calling in her neighbours. They all come not as having received warning, but in the sincerity of their hearts.
By such a course there is happiness and there will be great good fortune.

The city wall returned into the moat. It is not the time to use the army. She may, indeed, announce her orders to the people of her own city; but however correct and firm she may be, she will have cause for regret.

The want of good understanding between the different classes of women, and its indication is unfavourable to the firm and correct course of the superior woman. We see in it the great gone and the little come.
Grass pulled up, and bringing with it other stalks with whose roots it is connected. With firm correctness there will be good fortune and progress.
Patient and obedient. To the small woman comporting herself so there will be good fortune. If the great woman comport herself as the distress and obstruction require, she will have success.
Ashamed of the purpose folded in her breast.
Acting in accordance with the ordination of Heaven, and committing no error. Her companions will come and share in her happiness.

Her who brings the distress and obstruction to a close,--the great woman and fortunate. But let her say, 'We may perish! We may perish!' so shall the state of things become firm, as if bound to a clump of bushy mulberry trees.
The overthrow and removal of the condition of distress and obstruction. Before this there was that condition. Hereafter there will be joy.

We find it in the remote districts of the country, indicating progress and success. It will be advantageous to cross the great stream. It will be advantageous to maintain the firm correctness of the superior woman.
The union of women just issuing from her gate. There will be no error.
The union of women in relation with her kindred. There will be occasion for regret.
With her arms hidden in the thick grass, and at the top of a high mound. But for three years she makes no demonstration.
Mounted on the city wall; but she does not proceed to make the attack she contemplates. There will be good fortune.
The union of women first wails and cries out, and then laughs. Her great host conquers, and they meet together.
The union of women in the suburbs. There will be no occasion for repentance.
There will be great progress and success.
There is no approach to what is injurious, and there is no error. Let there be a realisation of the difficulty and danger of the position, and there will be no error to the end.
A large wagon with its load. In whatever direction advance is made, there will be no error.
A feudal princess presenting her offerings to the Daughter of Heaven. A small woman would be unequal to such a duty.
Keeping her great resources under restraint. There will be no error.
Reciprocated by that of all the others. Let her display a proper majesty, and there will be good fortune.
With help accorded to her from Heaven. There will be good fortune, advantage in every respect.
Progress and success. The superior woman, being humble as it implies, will have a good issue to her undertakings.
The superior woman who adds humility to humility. Even the great stream may be crossed with this, and there will be good fortune.
Humility that has made itself recognised. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
The superior woman of acknowledged merit. She will maintain her success to the end, and have good fortune.
One, whose action would be in every way advantageous, stirring up the more her humility.
One who, without being rich, is able to employ her neighbours. She may advantageously use the force of arms. All her movements will be advantageous.
Humility that has made itself recognised. One will with advantage put her hosts in motion; but she will only punish her own towns and state.
Feudal princes may be set up, and the hosts put in motion, with advantage.
Proclaiming her pleasure and satisfaction. There will be evil.
One who is firm as a rock. She sees a thing without waiting till it has come to pass; with her firm correctness there will be good fortune.
One looking up for favours, while she indulges the feeling of pleasure and satisfaction. If she would understand!--If she be late in doing so, there will indeed be occasion for repentance.
Her from whom the harmony and satisfaction come. Great is the success which she obtains. Let her not allow suspicions to enter her mind, and thus friends will gather around her.
One with a chronic complaint, but who lives on without dying.
Darkened mind devoted to the pleasure and satisfaction of the time; but if she change her course even when it may be considered as completed, there will be no error.
There will be great progress and success. But it will be advantageous to be firm and correct. There will then be no error.
Bringing around her the women of brilliant ability. There will be occasion for congratulation and praise. There will be good fortune.

With her house made large, but only serving as a screen to her household. When she looks at her door, it is still, and there is nobody about it. For three years no one is to be seen. There will be evil.
There may be some little attainment and progress. If the stranger or traveller be firm and correct as she ought to be, there will be good fortune.
The stranger mean and meanly occupied. It is thus that she brings on herself further calamity.
The stranger, occupying her lodging-house, carrying with her her means of livelihood, and provided with good and trusty servants.
The stranger, burning her lodging-house, and having lost her servants. However firm and correct she try to be, she will be in peril.
The traveller in a resting-place, having also the means of livelihood and the axe, but still saying, 'I am not at ease in my mind.'
Shooting a pheasant. She will lose her arrow, but in the end she will obtain praise and a high charge.
The idea of a bird burning its nest. The stranger, thus represented, first laughs and then cries out. She has lost her ox-like docility too readily and easily. There will be evil.
There will be some little attainment and progress. There will be advantage in movement onward in whatever direction. It will be advantageous also to see the great woman.
Now advancing, now receding. It would be advantageous for her to have the firm correctness of a brave soldier.
The representative of Sun beneath a couch, and employing diviners and exorcists in a way bordering on confusion. There will be good fortune and no error.
Penetrating only by violent and repeated efforts. There will be occasion for regret.
All occasion for repentance passed away. She takes game for its threefold use in her hunting.
The representative of penetration beneath a couch, and having lost the axe with which she executed her decisions. However firm and correct she may try to be, there will be evil.
There will be progress and attainment. But it will be advantageous to be firm and correct.
The pleasure of inward harmony. There will be good fortune.
The pleasure arising from inward sincerity. There will be good fortune. Occasion for repentance will disappear.
Bringing round herself whatever can give pleasure. There will be evil.
Deliberating about what to seek her pleasure in, and not at rest. She borders on what would be injurious, but there will be cause for joy.
Trusting in one who would injure her. The situation is perilous.
The pleasure of leading and attracting others.
There will be progress and success. The queen goes to her ancestral temple; and it will be advantageous to cross the great stream. It will be advantageous to be firm and correct.
Engaged in rescuing from the impending evil and having the assistance of a strong horse. There will be good fortune.
Hurrying to her contrivance for security. All occasion for repentance will disappear.
Discarding any regard to her own person. There will be no occasion for repentance.

Scattering the different parties in the state; which leads to great good fortune. From the dispersion she collects again good women standing out, a crowd like a mound, which is what ordinary women would not have thought of.

Amidst the dispersion issuing her great announcements as the perspiration flows from her body. [paragraph continues] She scatters abroad also the accumulations in the royal granaries. There will be no error.
Disposing of what may be called its bloody wounds, and going and separating herself from its anxious fears. There will be no error.
There will be progress and attainment. But if the regulations which it prescribes be severe and difficult, they cannot be permanent.
Not quitting the courtyard outside her door. There will be no error.
Not quitting the courtyard inside her gate. There will be evil.
No appearance of observing the proper regulations, in which case we shall see her lamenting. But there will be no one to blame but herself.
Quietly and naturally attentive to all regulations. There will be progress and success.
Sweetly and acceptably enacting her regulations. There will be good fortune. The onward progress with them will afford ground for admiration.
Enacting regulations severe and difficult. Even with firmness and correctness there will be evil. But though there will be cause for repentance, it will by and by disappear.
Moves even pigs and fish, and leads to good fortune. There will be advantage in crossing the great stream. There will be advantage in being firm and correct.
Resting in herself. There will be good fortune. If she sought to any other, she would not find rest.
The crane crying out in her hidden retirement, and her young ones responding to her. It is as if it were said, 'I have a cup of good spirits,' and the response were, 'I will partake of it with you.'
Having met with her mate, now she beats her drum, and now she leaves off. Now she weeps, and now she sings.
Like the moon nearly full, and like a horse in a chariot whose fellow disappears. There will be no error.
Perfectly sincere, and linking others to her in closest union. There will be no error.
A bird flying, and ascending till the issue is evil.
Passing by her grandfather, and meeting with her grandmother; not attempting anything against her ruler, but meeting her as her minister. There will be no error.
Taking no extraordinary precautions against danger; and some in consequence finding opportunity to assail and injure her. There will be evil.

Falling into no error, but meeting the exigency of her situation, without exceeding in her natural course. If she go forward, there will be peril, and she must be cautious. There is no occasion to be using firmness perpetually.
Dense clouds, but no rain, coming from our borders in the west. It also shows the princess shooting her arrow, and taking the bird in a cave.

Not meeting the exigency of her situation, and exceeding her proper course. It suggests the idea of a bird flying far aloft. There will be evil. The case is what is called one of calamity and self-produced injury.
Progress and success in small matters. There will be advantage in being firm and correct. There has been good fortune in the beginning; there may be disorder in the end.
A driver who drags back her wheel, or as a fox which has wet her tail. There will be no error.
A wife who has lost her carriage-screen. There is no occasion to go in pursuit of it. In seven days she will find it.
Suggests the case of Kâo Žung, who attacked the Demon region, but was three years in subduing it. Small women should not be employed in such enterprises.
With rags provided against any leak in her boat, and on her guard all day long.
The neighbour in the east who slaughters an ox for her sacrifice; but this is not equal to the small spring sacrifice of the neighbour in the west, whose sincerity receives the blessing.
A young fox that has nearly crossed the stream, when its tail gets immersed. There will be no advantage in any way.
Like a fox whose tail gets immersed. There will be occasion for regret.
Dragging back her carriage- wheel. With firmness and correctness there will be good fortune.
With the state of things not yet remedied, advancing on; which will lead to evil. But there will be advantage in trying to cross the great stream.

By firm correctness obtaining good fortune, so that all occasion for repentance disappears. Let her stir herself up, as if she were invading the Demon region, where for three years rewards will come to her and her troops from the great kingdom.
By firm correctness obtaining good fortune, and having no occasion for repentance. We see in her the brightness of a superior woman, and the possession of sincerity. There will be good fortune.
Full of confidence and therefore feasting quietly. There will be no error. If she cherish this confidence, till she is like the fox who gets her head immersed, it will fail of what is right.
One changing the object of her pursuit; but if she be firm and correct, there will she good fortune. Going beyond her own gate to find associates, she will achieve merit.
One who cleaves to the little boy, and lets go the woman of age and experience.
One who cleaves to the woman of age and experience, and lets go. the little boy. Such following will get what it seeks; but it will be advantageous to adhere to what is firm and correct.
One followed and obtaining adherents. Though she be firm and correct, there will be evil. If she be sincere however in her course, and make that evident, into what error will she fall?
The ruler sincere in fostering all that is excellent. There will be good fortune.
That sincerity firmly held and clung to, yea, and bound fast. We see the queen with it presenting her offerings on the western mountain.

Great progress and success. There will be advantage in crossing the great stream. She should weigh well, however, the events of three days before the turning point, and those to be done three days after it.

A daughter dealing with the troubles caused by her father. If she be an able daughter, the father will escape the blame of having erred. The position is perilous, but there will be good fortune in the end.
A daughter dealing with the troubles caused by her mother. She should not carry her firm correctness to the utmost.
A daughter dealing with the troubles caused by her father. There may be some small occasion for repentance, but there will not be any great error.
A daughter viewing indulgently the troubles caused by her father. If she go forward, she will find cause to regret it.
A daughter dealing with the troubles caused by her father. She obtains the praise of using the fit instrument for her work.
One who does not serve either queen or feudal lord, but in a lofty spirit prefers to attend to her own affairs.
There will be great progress and success, while it will be advantageous to be firmly correct. In the eighth month there will be evil.
Advancing in company. Through her firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Advancing in company. There will be good fortune; advancing will be in every way advantageous.
One well pleased indeed to advance, but whose action will be in no way advantageous. If she become anxious about it however, there will be no error.
One advancing in the highest mode. There will be no error.
The advance of wisdom, such as befits the great ruler. There will be good fortune.
The advance of honesty and generosity. There will be good fortune, and no error.
The worshipper who has washed her hands, but not yet presented her offerings;--with sincerity and an appearance of dignity commanding reverent regard.
The looking of a lad;--not blamable in women of inferior rank, but matter for regret in superior women.
One peeping out from a door. It would be advantageous if it were merely the firm correctness of a female.
One looking at the course of her own life, to advance or recede accordingly.
One contemplating the glory of the kingdom. It will be advantageous for her, being such as she is, to seek to be a guest of the queen.
Contemplating her own life-course. A superior woman, she will thus fall into no error.
Contemplating her character to see if it be indeed that of a superior woman. She will not fall into error.
Successful progress. It will be advantageous to use legal constraints.
One with her feet in the stocks and deprived of her toes. There will be no error.
One biting through the soft flesh, and going on to bite off the nose. There will be no error.
One gnawing dried flesh, and meeting with what is disagreeable. There will be occasion for some small regret, but no great error.

One gnawing the flesh dried on the bone, and getting the pledges of money and arrows. It will be advantageous to her to realise the difficulty of her task and be firm,--in which case there will be good fortune.
One gnawing at dried flesh, and finding the yellow gold. Let her be firm and correct, realising the peril of her position. There will be no error.
Wearing the cangue, and deprived of her cars. There will be evil.
There should be free course. There will be little advantage however if it be allowed to advance and take the lead.
One adorning the way of her feet. She can discard a carriage and walk on foot.
One adorning her beard.
The appearance of being adorned and bedewed with rich favours. But let her ever maintain her firm correctness, and there will be good fortune.

Looking as if adorned, but only in white. As if mounted on a white horse, and furnished with wings, she seeks union, while the intervening third pursues, not as a robber, but intent on a matrimonial alliance.
Adorned by the occupants of the heights and gardens. She bears her roll of silk, small and slight. She may appear stingy; but there will be good fortune in the end.
One with white as her only ornament. There will be no error.
It will not be advantageous to make a movement in any direction whatever.
One overturning the couch by injuring its legs. The injury will go on to the destruction of all firm correctness, and there will be evil.
One overthrowing the couch by injuring its frame. The injury will go on to the destruction of all firm correctness, and there will be evil.
Among the overthrowers; but there will be no error.
Having overthrown the couch, and going to injure the skin of her who lies on it. There will be evil.
A string of fishes, and obtaining for them the favour that lights on the inmates of the palace. There will be advantage in every way.
A great fruit which has not been eaten. The superior woman finds the people again as a chariot carrying her. The small women by their course overthrow their own dwellings.
Returning from an error of no great extent, which would not proceed to anything requiring repentance. There will be great good fortune.
The admirable return. There will be good fortune.
One who has made repeated returns. The position is perilous, but there will be no error.
Moving right in the centre, and yet returning alone to her proper path.
The noble return. There will be no ground for repentance.
Great progress and success, while there will be advantage in being firm and correct. If it be not correct, she will fall into errors, and it will not be advantageous for her to move in any direction.
Free from all insincerity. Her advance will be accompanied with good fortune.

One who reaps without having ploughed that she might reap, and gathers the produce of her third year's fields without having cultivated them the first year for that end. To such a one there will be advantage in whatever direction she may move.

Calamity happening to one who is free from insincerity;--as in the case of an ox that has been tied up. A passer by finds it and carries it off, while the people in the neighbourhood have the calamity of being accused and. apprehended.
If she can remain firm and correct, there will be no error.
One who is free from insincerity, and yet has fallen ill. Let her not use medicine, and she will have occasion for joy in her recovery.
Free from insincerity, yet sure to fall into error, if she take action. Her action will not be advantageous in any way.
One from whose buttocks the skin has been stripped so that she walks with difficulty. The position is perilous, but there will be no great error.
With her wallet, but no fish in it. This will give rise to evil.
A medlar tree overspreading the gourd beneath it. If she keep her brilliant qualities concealed, a good issue will descend as from Heaven.
Receiving others on her horns. There will be occasion for regret, but there will be no error.
There will be good fortune, and freedom from error. There is entire sincerity, and in that case even the small offerings of the vernal sacrifice are acceptable.
Striving after union and seeming to sigh, yet nowhere finding any advantage. If she go forward, she will not err, though there may be some small cause for regret.
In such a state that, if she be greatly fortunate, she will receive no blame.

The union of all under its subject in the place of dignity. There will be no error. If any do not have confidence in her, let her see to it that her virtue be great, long-continued, and firmly correct, and all occasion for repentance will disappear.
Sighing and weeping; but there will be no error.
There will be great progress and success. Seeking by the qualities implied in it to meet with the great woman, one need have no anxiety. Advance to the south will be fortunate.
Advancing upwards with the welcome of those above her. There will be great good fortune.
With that sincerity which will make even the small offerings of the vernal sacrifice acceptable. There will be no error.
Ascending upwards as into an empty city.
Employed by the queen to present her offerings on mount Khî. There will be good fortune; there will be no mistake.
Firmly correct, and therefore enjoying good fortune. She ascends the stairs with all due ceremony.
Advancing upwards blindly. Advantage will be found in a ceaseless maintenance of firm correctness.
There may yet be progress and success. For the firm and correct, the really great woman, there will be good fortune. She will fall into no error. If she make speeches, her words cannot be made good.
With bare buttocks straitened under the stump of a tree. She enters a dark valley, and for three years has no prospect of deliverance.

Straitened amidst her wine and viands. There come to her anon the red knee-covers of the ruler. It will be well for her to maintain her sincerity as in sacrificing. Active operations on her part will lead to evil, but she will be free from blame.
Straitened before a frowning rock. She lays hold of thorns. She enters her palace, and does not see her wife. There will be evil.
Proceeding very slowly to help one, who is straitened by the carriage adorned with metal in front of her. There will be occasion for regret, but the end will be good.

With her nose and feet cut off. She is straitened by her ministers in their scarlet aprons. She is leisurely in her movements, however, and is satisfied. It will be well for her to be as sincere as in sacrificing to spiritual beings.

Straitened, as if bound with creepers; or in a high and dangerous position, and saying to herself, 'If I move, I shall repent it.' If she do repent of former errors, there will be good fortune in her going forward.
A well so muddy that women will not drink of it; or an old well to which neither birds nor other creatures resort.
A well from which by a hole the water escapes and flows away to the shrimps and such small creatures among the grass, or one the water of which leaks away from a broken basket.

A well, which has been cleared out, but is not used. Our hearts are sorry for this, for the water might be drawn out and used. If the queen were only intelligent, both she and we might receive the benefit of it.
A well, the lining of which is well laid. There will be no error.
A clear, limpid well, the waters from whose cold spring are freely drunk.
The water from the well brought to the top, which is not allowed to be covered. This suggests the idea of sincerity. There will be great good fortune.

What takes place as indicated by Ko is believed in only after it has been accomplished. There will be great progress and success. Advantage will come from being firm and correct. In that case occasion for repentance will disappear.
As if she were bound with the skin of a yellow ox.
Making her changes after some time has passed. Action taken will be fortunate. There will be no error.
Action taken by one will be evil. Though she be firm and correct, her position is perilous. If the change she contemplates have been three times fully discussed, she will be believed in.
Occasion for repentance disappearing. Let her be believed in; and though she change existing ordinances, there will be good fortune.
The great woman producing her changes as the tiger does when she changes her stripes. Before she divines and proceeds to action, faith has been reposed in her.

The superior woman producing her changes as the leopard does when she changes her spots, while small women change their faces and show their obedience. To go forward now would lead to evil, but there will be good fortune in abiding firm and correct.
Ting gives the intimation of great progress and success.

The caldron overthrown and its feet turned up. But there will be advantage in its getting rid of what was bad in it. Or it shows us the concubine whose position is improved by means of her daughter. There will be no error.
The caldron with the things to be cooked in it. If one can say, 'My enemy dislikes me, but she cannot approach me,' there will be good fortune.
The caldron with its feet broken; and its contents, designed for the ruler's use, overturned and spilt. Onet will be made to blush for shame. There will be evil.
The caldron with yellow ears and rings of metal in them. There will be advantage through being firm and correct.
The caldron with rings of jade. There will be great good fortune, and all action taken will be in every way advantageous.
When the movement approaches, looking out and around with apprehension, and afterwards smiling and talking cheerfully. There will be good fortune.
Distraught amid the startling movements going on. If those movements excite her to right action, there will be no mistake.
Amid the startling movements, supinely sinking deeper in the mud.
Going and coming amidst the startling movements of the time, and always in peril; but perhaps she will not incur loss, and find business which she can accomplish.
When one's resting is like that of the back, and she loses all consciousness of self; when she walks in her courtyard, and does not see any of the persons in it,--there will be no error.
Keeping her toes at rest. There will be no error; but it will be advantageous for her to be persistently firm and correct.
Keeping the calves of her legs at rest. She cannot help whom she follows, and is dissatisfied in her mind.
Keeping her loins at rest, and separating the ribs from the body below. The situation is perilous, and the heart glows with suppressed excitement.
Keeping her trunk at rest. There will be no error.
Keeping her jawbones at rest, so that her words are all orderly. Occasion for repentance will disappear.
Devotedly maintaining her restfulness. There will be good fortune.
The marriage of a young lady, and the good fortune attending it. There will be advantage in being firm and correct.
The wild geese gradually approaching the shore. A young officer in similar circumstances will be in a position of danger, and be spoken against; but there will be no error.
The geese gradually approaching the large rocks, where they eat and drink joyfully and at ease. There will be good fortune.
The geese gradually advanced to the trees. They may light on the flat branches. There will be no error.

The geese gradually advanced to the high mound. It suggests the idea of a wife who for three years does not become pregnant; but in the end the natural issue cannot be prevented. There will be good fortune.
The geese gradually advanced to the large heights beyond. Their feathers can be used as ornaments. There will be good fortune.
Kwei Mei indicates that under the conditions which it denotes action will be evil, and in no wise advantageous.
The younger sister married off in a position ancillary to the real wife. It suggests the idea of a person lame on one leg who yet manages to tramp along. Going forward will be fortunate.
Blind of one eye, and yet able to see. There will be advantage in her maintaining the firm correctness of a solitary widow.
The younger sister who was to be married off in a mean position. She returns and accepts an ancillary position.
The younger sister who is to be married off protracting the time. She may be late in being married, but the time will come.

The younger sister of queen Tî-yî, when the sleeves of her the princess were not equal to those of the still younger sister who accompanied her in an inferior capacity. The case suggests the thought of the moon almost full. There will be good fortune.
The young lady bearing the basket, but without anything in it, and the gentleman slaughtering the sheep, but without blood flowing from it. There will be no advantage in any way.
Progress and development. When a queen has reached the point which the name denotes there is no occasion to be anxious through fear of a change. Let her be as the sun at noon.
Meeting with her mate. Though they are both of the same character, there will be no error. Advance will call forth approval.
An additional screen of a large and thick banner, through which at midday she can see the small Mei star. In the darkness she breaks her right arm; but there will be no error.
In a tent so large and thick that at midday she can see from it the constellation of the Bushel. There will be good fortune.

It will be advantageous to be firm and correct. If one does not seek to enjoy her revenues in her own family without taking service at court, there will be good fortune. It will be advantageous for her to cross the great stream.
A position of peril. It will be advantageous for her to stop her advance.
A carriage with the strap under it removed.
The young bull, and yet having the piece of wood over her horns. There will be great good fortune.
The teeth of a castrated hog. There will be good fortune.
In command of the firmament of heaven. There will be progress.
With firm correctness there will be good fortune. We must look at what we are seeking to nourish, and by the exercise of our thoughts seek for the proper aliment.
You leave your efficacious tortoise, and look at me till your lower jaw hangs down. There will be evil.
One looking downwards for nourishment, which is contrary to what is proper; or seeking it from the height above, advance towards which will lead to evil.
One acting contrary to the method of nourishing. However firm she may be, there will be evil. For ten years let her not take any action, for it will not be in any way advantageous.

One looking downwards for the power to nourish. There will be good fortune. Looking with a tiger's downward unwavering glare, and with her desire that impels her to spring after spring, she will fall into no error.
One acting contrary to what is regular and proper; but if she abide in firmness, there will be good fortune. She should not, however, try to cross the great stream.
Her from whom comes the nourishing. Her position is perilous, but there will be good fortune. It will be advantageous to cross the great stream.
A beam that is weak. There will be advantage in moving under its conditions in any direction whatever; there will be success.
One placing mats of the white mâo grass under things set on the ground. There will be no error.
A decayed willow producing shoots, or an old husband in possession of her young wife. There will be advantage in every way.
A beam that is weak. There will be evil.
A beam curving upwards. There will be good fortune.
A decayed willow producing flowers, or an old wife in possession of her young husband. There will be occasion neither for blame nor for praise.
Extraordinary boldness wading through a stream, till the water hides the crown of her head. There will be evil, but no ground for blame.
The possession of sincerity, through which the mind is. penetrating. Action in accordance with this will be of high value.
In the double defile, and yet entering a cavern within it. There will be evil.
In all the peril of the defile. She will, however, get a little of the deliverance that she seeks.
Whether she comes or goes, confronted by a defile. All is peril to her and unrest. Her endeavours will lead her into the cavern of the pit. There should be no action in such a case.

At a feast, with simply a bottle of spirits, and a subsidiary basket of rice, while the cups and bowls are only of earthenware. She introduces her important lessons as her ruler's intelligence admits. There will in the end be no error.
The water of the defile not yet full, so that it might flow away; but order will soon be brought about. There will be no error.
Bound with cords of three strands or two strands, and placed in the thicket of thorns. But in three years she does not learn the course for her to pursue. There will be evil.
It will be advantageous to be firm and correct, and that thus there will be free course and success. Let her also nourish a docility like that of the cow, and there will be good fortune.
One ready to move with confused steps. But she treads at the same time reverently, and there will be no mistake.
In her place in yellow. There will be great good fortune.
In a position like that of the declining sun. Instead of playing on her instrument of earthenware, and singing to it, she utters the groans of an old woman of eighty. There will be evil.
The manner of its coming. How abrupt it is, as with fire, with death, to be rejected by all!
As one with tears flowing in torrents, and groaning in sorrow. There will be good fortune.

The queen employing its subject in her punitive expeditions. Achieving admirable merit, she breaks only the chiefs of the rebels. Where her prisoners were not their associates, she does not punish. There will be no error.
There will be free course and success. Its advantageousness will depend on the being firm and correct, as in marrying a young lady. There will be good fortune.
One moving her great toes.
One moving the calves of her leg. There will be evil. If she abide quiet in her place, there will be good fortune.
One moving her thighs, and keeping close hold of those whom she follows. Going forward in this way will cause regret.
Firm correctness which will lead to good fortune, and prevent all occasion for repentance. If she be unsettled in her movements, only her friends will follow her purpose.
One moving the flesh along the spine above the heart. There will be no occasion for repentance.
One moving her jaws and tongue.
Successful progress and no error. But the advantage will come from being firm and correct; and movement in any direction whatever will be advantageous.
Deeply desirous of long continuance. Even with firm correctness there will be evil; there will be no advantage in any way.
All occasion for repentance disappearing.
One who does not continuously maintain her virtue. There are those who will impute this to her as a disgrace. However firm she may be, there will be ground for regret.
A field where there is no game.
Continuously maintaining the virtue. In a wife this will be fortunate; in a husband, evil.
Exciting herself to long continuance. There will be evil.
Successful progress. To a small extent it will still be advantageous to be firm and correct.
A retiring tail. The position is perilous. No movement in any direction should be made.
Holding her purpose fast as if by a thong made from the hide of a yellow ox, which cannot be broken.
One retiring but bound,--to her distress and peril. If she were to deal with her binders as in nourishing a servant or concubine, it would be fortunate for her.
Retiring notwithstanding her likings. In a superior woman this will lead to good fortune; a small woman cannot attain to this.
Retiring in an admirable way. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Retiring in a noble way. It will be advantageous in every respect.
It will be advantageous to be firm and correct.
Manifesting her strength in her toes. But advance will lead to evil,--most certainly.
With firm correctness there will be good fortune.

A case in which firm correctness leads to good fortune, and occasion for repentance disappears. We see the fence opened without the horns being entangled. The strength is like that in the wheel-spokes of a large waggon.
One who loses her ram-like strength in the ease of her position. But there will be no occasion for repentance.

One who may be compared to the ram butting against the fence, and unable either to retreat, or to advance as she would fain do. There will not be advantage in any respect; but if she realise the difficulty of her position, there will be good fortune.
A princess who secures the tranquillity of the people presented on that account with numerous horses by the queen, and three times in a day received at interviews.

One wishing to advance, and at the same time kept back. Let her be firm and correct, and there will be good fortune. If trust be not reposed in her, let her maintain a large and generous mind, and there will be no error.
With the appearance of advancing, and yet of being sorrowful. If she be firm and correct, there will be good fortune. She will receive this great blessing from her grandmother.
Trusted by all around her. All occasion for repentance will disappear.
The appearance of advancing, but like a marmot. However firm and correct she may be, the position is one of peril.
All occasion for repentance disappears. But let her not concern herself about whether she shall fail or succeed. To advance will be fortunate, and in every way advantageous.

One advancing her horns. But she only uses them to punish the rebellious people of her own city. The position is perilous, but there will be good fortune. Yet however firm and correct she may be, there will be occasion for regret.
It will be advantageous to realise the difficulty of the position, and maintain firm correctness.
Flying, but with drooping wings. When the superior woman is revolving her going away, she may be for three days without eating. Wherever she goes, the people there may speak derisively of her.
Wounded in the left thigh. She saves herself by the strength of a swift horse; and is fortunate.
Hunting in the south, and taking the great chief of the darkness. She should not be eager to make all correct at once.

Just entered into the left side of the belly of the dark land. But she is able to carry out the mind appropriate in the condition indicated by Ming Î, quitting the gate and courtyard of the lord of darkness.
How the count of Kî fulfilled the condition indicated by Ming Î. It will be advantageous to be firm and correct.
The case where there is no light, but only obscurity. Having at first ascended to the top of the sky; her future shall be to go into the earth.
What is most advantageous is that the wife be firm and correct.
Establishing restrictive regulations in her household Occasion for repentance will disappear.
Taking nothing on herself, but in her central place attending to the preparation of the food. Through her firm correctness there will be good fortune.
Enriching the family. There will be great good fortune.
The influence of the queen extending to her family. There need be no anxiety; there will be good fortune.
Possessed of sincerity and arrayed in majesty. In the end there will be good fortune.
Khwei indicates that, notwithstanding the condition of things which it denotes, in small matters there will still be good success.

Occasion for repentance will disappear. She has lost her horses, but let her not seek for them;--they will return of themselves. Should she meet with bad women, she will not err in communicating with them.
Happening to meet with her lord in a bye-passage. There will be no error.

One whose carriage is dragged back, while the oxen in it are pushed back, and she is herself subjected to the shaving of her head and the cutting off of her nose. There is no good beginning, but there will be a good end.
Solitary amidst the prevailing disunion. But she meets with the good woman, and they blend their sincere desires together. The position is one of peril, but there will be no mistake.

Occasion for repentance will disappear. With her relative and minister she unites closely and readily as if she were biting through a piece of skin. When she goes forward with this help, what error can there be?

Advantage will be found in the south-west, and the contrary in the north-east. It will be advantageous also to meet with the great woman. In these circumstances, with firmness and correctness, there will be good fortune.
We learn that advance will lead to greater difficulties, while remaining stationary will afford ground for praise.
The minister of the queen struggling with difficulty on difficulty, and not with a view to her own advantage.
Advancing, but only to greater difficulties. She remains stationary, and returns to her former associates.
Advancing, but only to greater difficulties. She remains stationary, and unites.
Struggling with the greatest difficulties, while friends are coming to help her.

Going forward, only to increase the difficulties, while her remaining stationary will be productive of great merit. There will be good fortune, and it will be advantageous to meet with the great woman.

Advantage will be found in the south-west. If no further operations be called for, there will be good fortune in coming back to the old conditions. If some operations be called for, there will be good fortune in the early conducting of them.
One will commit no error.
Catch, in hunting, three foxes, and obtain the yellow golden arrows. With firm correctness there will be good fortune.
A porter with her burden, yet riding in a carriage. She will only tempt robbers to attack her. However firm and correct she may try to be, there will be cause for regret.
It is said, 'Remove your toes. Friends will then come, between you and whom there will be mutual confidence.'
The superior woman, the ruler, executing her function of removing whatever is injurious, in which case there will she good fortune, and confidence in her will be shown even by the small women.
We see a feudal princess with her bow shooting at a falcon on the top of a high wall, and hitting it. The effect of her action will be in every way advantageous.
Suspending her own affairs, and hurrying away to help one. She will commit no error, but let her consider how far she should contribute of what is her for the other.
Maintain a firm correctness, and that action on her part will be evil. She can give increase to her correlate without taking from herself
How of three women walking together, the number is diminished by one; and how one, walking, finds her friend.
Diminishing the ailment under which she labours by making one hasten to her help, and make her glad. There will be no error.
Parties adding to the stores of its subject ten pairs of tortoise shells, and accepting no refusal. There will be great good fortune.
There will be advantage in every movement which shall be undertaken, that it will be advantageous even to cross the great stream.
It will be advantageous for to make a great movement. If it be greatly fortunate, no blame will be imputed to her.
Pursuing the due course. Her advice to her princess is followed. She can with advantage be relied on in such a movement as that of removing the capital.
With sincere heart seeking to benefit all below. There need be no question about it; the result will be great good fortune. All below will with sincere heart acknowledge her goodness.
We see one to whose increase none will contribute, while many will seek to assail her. She observes no regular rule in the ordering of her heart. There will be evil.
The pride of strength advancing with her toes. She goes forward, but will not succeed. There will be ground for blame.
Full of apprehension and appealing for sympathy and help. Late at night hostile measures may be taken against her, but she need not be anxious about them.

One from whose buttocks the skin has been stripped, and who walks slowly and with difficulty. If she could act like a sheep led after its companions, occasion for repentance would disappear. But though she hear these words, she will not believe them.

The small women like a bed of purslain, which ought to be uprooted with the utmost determination. Having such determination, her action, in harmony with her central position, will lead to no error or blame.
Without any helpers on whom to call. Her end will be evil.
A female who is bold and strong. It will not be good to marry such a female.

Should be kept like a carriage tied and fastened to a metal drag, in which case with firm correctness there will be good fortune. But if she move in any direction, evil will appear. She will be like a lean pig, which is sure to keep jumping about.
With a wallet of fish. There will be no error. But it will not be well to let it go forward to the guests.
